subtitle: [Music]
New Thinking
Allowed. Conversations on the leading edge
of knowledge and discovery with
parapsychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today, I'd like to talk about the locus of
control, and really,
this is a very important monologue
because
it has to do with your success
in life actually. Now, it starts out with
a very
basic finding that, to my knowledge, has
been confirmed
many times within the field of
psychology
about a parameter called locus of
control.
That means, where do you believe
control of your life exists?
What is the location of that control? Is
it within you
or is it somewhere outside?
The research, to my knowledge, is
rather clear.
That people who consider themselves
successful
also believe that the locus of control
is within them.
People who are struggling with life, who
consider themselves
unsuccessful, and may well be
unsuccessful
by outside standards, they believe that they don't have
control, that they are the victim
of circumstances.
Now, many of you notice that I'm
always laughing and smiling during
these monologues, and some people think,
"It can't be real.
I mean, how is this guy so happy? He's
putting on an
act." I have to tell you, I was not
always this way.
There were times when people thought
of me as a very
serious person. I think there were times
when, if you had asked me, I would have
characterized myself
as tense and anguished.
But, you know, I'm in my 70s at this point,
and I can look back
and say, I must have done something right
somewhere along
the line, because I'm living the life of
my dreams. I'm
doing right at this moment, and this is
what I do pretty much every day,
what I'm most passionate about. I'm
following my bliss,
as Joseph Campbell would say, and I'm
surrounded by
supportive people in a beautiful
environment.
I have good health, and I'm
living a comfortable life.
So yes, I'm very happy. The truth is,
for many, many years, if you had asked me,
I would probably say, "I'm the happiest
person I know." But it didn't happen
automatically. I wasn't always that way.
There was a time in my life
when I was very distraught.
In fact, more than one time.
I'm going to give you two examples.
On one occasion, when I was just in
graduate school in Berkeley, in my second
year of graduate school there, I became the
head of a program I had written a grant
for. The grant got funded by the University
Chancellor,
and I was the Director of the Health
Information Program
on the Berkeley campus. I lived in
a special house provided by the
Chancellor
to run this program in, and we had a
board of directors and other people.
I got into a conflict with other people
I was working with,
and the conflict actually became violent.
I look back on it now,
I mean, I had boiling hot water thrown on
me. I had knives thrown
at me. I had these people saying they
wanted to kill me.
And then, when I went to the board of
directors to explain
what was going on, they said, "Well, the
simplest thing to do is get rid of
everybody," so I was kicked out of the
program that I was the head of,
for which I had written the grant.
For a long time, all I could think
about was how unfair it was,
how I had become the victim of
circumstances, and how
these terrible people... All I was trying
to do was
confront them about their dishonesty, and
then they got violent with me.
So I was blaming them, you see?
Now, in retrospect, from the perspective
of nearly
five decades, I can look back and laugh
at all of this, but at the time
it seemed very serious to me. If you
had talked to
any of my friends or colleagues back
then, they would have told you I was
insufferable,
because it was all I could talk about.
It was blame, blame, blame.
I finally got over it, after a few
months. In fact,
it was as a result of that
situation ending that I
began to open up and develop my own
career in the media, which is
really looking back now, I can say that's
on track. That's the purpose,
the mission of my life.
And then, another event happened. I got
involved, because I was in the media, I
found a way to create an individual,
interdisciplinary doctoral program
at Berkeley and worked on that program
for six years, maybe even seven,
as I recall. Finally, after much struggle,
much opposition within the university, I
got my doctoral degree in Parapsychology,
to this day,
a unique degree. I'm proud of it. I have
the only
doctoral diploma that says
Parapsychology,
to my knowledge, anywhere in the world.
Which is not to disparage the
hundreds of other people
who do wonderful doctoral research on
topics
related to parapsychology and who have
degrees
in more conventional disciplines,
philosophy, education,
psychology. In my case,
not only because my unique degree
made me virtually unhireable in academia,
which had been my ambition, but then I got
libeled.
I had to fight a libel suit for the
next six years.
If you had talked to me during that
very dark period of my life, I would have
said, you know, "I'm a victim. I got libeled."
It's preventing me from fulfilling my
destiny, fulfilling my dreams, being the
person I want to be.
It literally took me six years
fighting that libel suit to overcome it.
When I
finally settled the libel suit favorably,
it enabled me to buy some real estate in
California, which
that one purchase is probably the
single significant
basis for the small fortune I now enjoy.
But it also gave me the confidence to
set up the original Thinking Allowed
television series. Some of you may not
know that I had a national public television
series that ran
from 1986 to 2002, and many of those
videos
from the original Thinking Allowed TV
are on a separate YouTube channel, but
that's another story. My point
is, I know how hard it is to let go
of blame, to feeling yourself a
victim. It took me years to overcome it,
and if somebody had come along
like me today and said, "Get off of it, you
don't need to do that,"
I don't know if I would have been
capable of it.
And I say that now because I know that
there are those of you
who comment on the videos and who watch
these videos,
who post notices telling me that you
feel victimized. Very often
I hear,
"It's the elite." The elite people are
controlling your life.
Some of you are more specific. It's
the elite Jesuits,
it's the elite Freemasons, it's the elite
Jews, it's whoever it is for you.
And I'm here to tell you that you will do
so much better when you can regain the
locus of control and find it within
yourself. You don't have to be
the victim of outside circumstances.
I think one of the finest examples of
this is exemplified by a book I finished
reading recently called, The
Choice, by Dr. Edith Eva
Eger. Now, Dr. Eger, I hope to have her as a
guest on this program - I don't know if it
will happen -
is well into her 90s. She
was at Auschwitz. She came to Auschwitz
as a teenager.
Her parents were murdered by the Nazis
in Auschwitz.
She suffered unimaginable
hardships, was left for
dead with broken bones,
and had to recover and rebuild her life.
It didn't happen
overnight, it wasn't easy. But
today, she's still functioning as a working
psychologist. She seems like a healthy,
happy person. She had to overcome
unspeakable trauma, and she writes in
this book
actually about forgiving Hitler. Now, she
didn't do it for Hitler's sake, and she
certainly
didn't transcend all of the horrors that
she lived through.
They're still part of who she is and
part of her memory,
but she realized that every
step along the way, no matter
how much she was victimized, and I can
tell you she was victimized as much as
any living human being probably has ever
been victimized or
right up there as close as you can get,
far more than anyone that I know
personally has been victimized.
But her message is, "You always have a choice."
There are always some decisions that you
can make for yourself.
They may be small, they may seem
insignificant, but they are
under your control. You are never
a total victim. Even if you are being
tortured slowly,
you can control to some degree,
to even a small degree, your state of
mind.
I've talked before on, I'm going to
link to it, an “In Presence”
monologue, in which I mention
that it just takes a tiny shift, a
tiny shift of consciousness
to enter into a
different mindset.
It can be done. Actually, to make a
tiny change is not too hard.
Particularly for those of you who
feel
that you don't have control over your
life,
I want to suggest to you to look for the
little changes that you can make, to
pay attention to the choices that you do
have, rather than the choices that you imagine
you don't have.
I don't mean to suggest that
it's all in your imagination either.
For sure, it's not all in your
imagination.
It wasn't in my imagination when people
threw boiling hot water on me
or knives at me and said they intended to kill me.
That was very real. But I'll tell you
something. I found an
incredible resource within myself.
I was in my bed sleeping at the time, and
I stood up bare naked, as
these people had entered my bedroom
and expressed an intent to kill me.
Somehow I found within myself
a spirit. I think of it as the spirit of
Jesus Christ, as a matter of fact. I just
looked at them with a look
of total innocence and peace,
and they ran away.
We all have those inner resources,
those unbelievable
inner resources available to us.
Let me close by asking you, where do
you feel that your life is out of your
control, that
you are the victim of circumstances?
What choices are you still
able to make in spite of that
imprisoning circumstance?
Thank you for being with me.
[Music]
